title: Do we read to show off?
intro: What do you read when you are on the bus or train? Some people might hold a copy of a classic novel to impress other commuters. Neil and Alice discuss people's reading habits. Listen to the programme and learn new vocabulary.
this_week_question: b) the same number of classic books?
c) fewer classic books than they used to?
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: a person who has studied a lot and knows a lot about their area of study show off someone who does something well and always wants others to know that
entertaining and easy reading material, such as romantic fiction
very difficult reading material, such as academic textbooks
people or shops that sell things
culture (book, art, theatre) that intellectuals enjoy
addicted advent (here) beginning e-reader electronic device that contains lots of written text

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: … and I'm Alice. Sorry, wait a minute Neil. I'm just finishing this book.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Last page… nearly there… ohh - fantastic book!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well I'm glad you enjoyed that. I'm glad you finished your book there Alice! We're talking about books in today's programme. What was it you were reading there?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No, never mind Neil. It's not your kind of book. You wouldn't like it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: How do you know?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, I just think you might read something a little more intellectual.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh I see… Well we are talking about the kinds of books people read and what they say about them today.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. Perhaps you read the works of a famous writer – the classics – Charles Dickens, Shakespeare.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: People will think you are an intellectual. You can show off by reading these books – the classics.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Or perhaps you read popular novels or romantic fiction – a light easy read.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: When you go on holiday – maybe to the beach – what kind of books do you read? And what do you read when you're going to work?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: We're going to hear part of a BBC interview with David Adshead from the Commuter Book Club. A commuter travels to work by bus, train or here in London, The Tube, a train that goes all over the city, mostly underground.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And Alice as usual, we have a quiz question. Are you ready?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, absolutely.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. It's about classic book sales. So these days are people buying…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Oh that's an interesting one. Tricky to guess but I'm going to say c) fewer classic books.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, well, let’s find out the answer at the end of the programme. But now, here is David Adshead from the Commuter Club. What kind of book does he say people usually take with them to the beach?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: David Adshead, Commuter Book Club People often think that, you know, traditionally you take a light easy read for the beach and on the train, um, you maybe read something very different.

transcript.author: Interviewer
transcript.text: … if only to show off.

transcript.author: David Adshead
transcript.text: Exactly, to appear to others to be more intellectual. But actually, what we find in this is that it really comes down to the individual – what they like to read and actually we've seen this summer a lot of the book sales - summer reads is generally lighter books, easier to get on with, to take away on holiday - but the big retailers have seen a shift actually - people moving sort of slightly higher brow, taking away more classic books. Sales in that way have increased.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: David Adshead from the Commuter Book Club there. He says that people usually – traditionally - take a light, easy read to the beach or on the train.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. He says these books are easier to get on with. David says that it really comes down to the individual - each person is different. But he says that there has been a shift – a change – in what people read.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, he says that the shops that sell books – that's the retailers – say the books people are buying are more highbrow – the classics, as we were talking about.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Absolutely. Highbrow books are read by intellectuals or perhaps the people who read these books are just showing off.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, maybe they are. Well I wonder if these people have read any books by Fiona Harper. She writes romantic novels – that's stories about love.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Light reading – not highbrow. She was also at this interview about the Commuter Book Club.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now, do commuters read her romantic novels on the Tube?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well here is novelist Fiona Harper talking about how she writes her romantic novels. She wants people to not stop reading her stories once they start – she wants them to be hooked.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Author Fiona Harper I think what it comes down to most of the time is you just want to write a really good story because if you write a good story then hopefully people are hooked, they'll keep turning the pages and..

transcript.author: Interviewer
transcript.text: And do you wonder whether they are reading them on holiday? I mean presumably, they're more likely to read your stuff on holiday than when they’re sitting on the Tube being looked at by lots of other people. I don't know. Author Fiona Harper Possibly, although with the advent of e-readers, you can read anything you like and no one knows – or on your phone – no one knows what you're reading. Interviewer And that's an important point.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's the author Fiona Harper talking about romantic novels. So do commuters read her books on the Tube?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well perhaps you don't want others to see you reading that stuff. It can be a bit embarrassing. It shouldn't be, but Fiona says you can also use an e-reader.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: An e-reader – that's an electronic book. Instead of pages, you read off a screen.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well if you use an e-reader or tablet, no one knows what you're reading.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So perhaps they are reading a romantic novel – no one knows. OK. Let's take a moment to look at some of today's words.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Here they are:

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And before we go, the answer to today's quiz question. I asked about classic books. Are people these days buying…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. And I said c) fewer classic books.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well I'm afraid to say Alice that you're wrong.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Oh no.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I know. They're reading more classic books!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Oh excellent!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sales of these books are apparently increasing.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well that's good to hear.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please do join us again soon.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And keep reading books… in English. Highbrow classics or a light read – it doesn't matter.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It doesn't matter at all.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
